.22lr won't penetrate a Kevlar vest, but a .22mag will, as will the new .17hmr. They just have too much velocity compared to surface area and the Kevlar can't dissipate the energy and prevent it from exiting.

 To me, armor piercing bullets would be classified as bullets meant specifically to penetrate steel/aluminum plating with tungsten or steel cores. Most legislation though is way too loose on their text specifications and would easily allow the banning of hunting firearms and cartridges. My personal opinion is they should be legal for citizens to own so long as they can own a firearm (not a felon, etc). The 2nd Amendment isn't there to protect hunting and target shooting.

I agree with those who say the general public does not have a real need for armor piercing bullets. However, there are some readily available non-AP bullets that can do terrific harm to light armor. There are several .50 caliber hand guns on the market now. Muzzle energy of 2600 ft lbs is hard to stop even with light armor. Even in a flak jacket, I'd hate to be hit square in the sternum with one.

 True.
 
 Besides steel cored ammo is not neccessarily AP. They only used steel for a filler as it's usually cheaper than lead. The steel used is also generally a mild steel, MUCH softer than whats required for AP purposes.
daewoo

In order for AP rounds to be illegal, they have to be specifically listed by the ATF. Some manufactureres have challenged the ATF's rulings in court and won (which is why no 30-06 ammo is on the "AP" restricted list, since all 30-06 ammo is capable of blowing through most body armour like it is tissue paper).
 
 The steel core rounds were placed on there not really because they are AP (since 7.62x39 is a poor AP round, even with a steel core). Soviet military rounds that were sold extensively in the 80's and early 90's carried an iron or steel core because, as pointed out earlier, it is cheaper than lead. They were looking for a backdoor way to ban the importation of huge quantities of incredibly cheap 7.62x39. I bought some of this several years ago in africa, and you can get it for less than a penny per round (cheaper than .22). 
 
 The ATF saw a scenario where people might stockpile hundreds of thousands of rounds of ammo that cheap, and they are preventing that cheap ammo from being available ot the American public by listing it as AP and therefore banned.
 
 This is really not a bid thing, as most of that "export only" ammo that was made by russia was incredibly cheap, shoddy stuff. Casings were often irregular and thay had truly bizarre ballistic properties (most likely due to each round being a slightly different weight becuase the steel or iorn cores were not standardized)
